å…¨éƒ¨ç¿»è¯‘æˆè‡ªç„¶å¥½ç†è§£çš„äººè¯~ name: Intent Proposal Policy role: forward_intention_generation audience: llm description: > This policy describes what kinds of intentions an Agent may reasonably consider, given the current context and visible events. It does not enforce legality or correctness. intentions: open_request: description: > A publicly visible request for help or collaboration, without specifying a particular responder. typical_thoughts: - I might acknowledge the request. - I could offer to help, even if I'm not fully sure yet. - I may ask for clarification before committing. candidate_actions: - speak - submit cautions: - Do not assume exclusive ownership of the task. - Avoid implying completion unless submitting a result. direct_request: description: > A request explicitly addressed to this Agent. typical_thoughts: - I should respond, even if only to accept or decline. - I may negotiate scope or timing. - I can redirect if I'm not suitable. candidate_actions: - speak - submit cautions: - Ignoring the request may be interpreted negatively. - Submitting without understanding the request is risky. public_statement: description: > A statement made in the public scope, visible to all participants. typical_thoughts: - I want to share information or an opinion publicly. - I believe this is relevant to the group as a whole. candidate_actions: - speak_public cautions: - Public statements have lasting impact. - Premature conclusions may affect group decisions.

All rules are deterministic and enforceable. intentions: open_request: applies_to: event_type: request_anyone responder_constraints: exclude_sender: true scope_visible: true allowed_actions: - speak - submit forbidden_actions: - evaluation - state_change - join_group - leave_group direct_request: applies_to: event_type: request_specific responder_constraints: must_be_recipient: true scope_visible: true allowed_actions: - speak - submit forbidden_actions: - evaluation - state_change - join_group - leave_group public_statement: applies_to: event_type: - speak_public responder_constraints: scope_visible: true allowed_actions: - speak_public forbidden_actions: - submit - evaluation - state_change

è¿™ä»½æŠ¥å‘Šå¤ªæŠ€æœ¯äº†ï¼Œdeepseekå°å§ï¼Œæˆ‘çœ‹ä¸æ‡‚å•Šã€‚ä½ å¾—ç”¨å½¢è±¡çš„ä¸­æ–‡è®²ç»™æˆ‘å¬ Findings on nonâ€‘standard references Core event construction still accepts raw references without enforcing the â€œ{event_id, weight{stance/inspiration/dependency}}â€ shape. The low-level _new_event helper and public speak/speak_public/submit/state_change/group methods in agents/agent.py simply pass through whatever list is provided, so callers can (and tests do) supply bare event_id strings with no weight fields before the events reach the store. The general-purpose new_event constructor in events/types.py also forwards references unchanged, meaning any code path that builds events via this helper can emit unweighted string references unless upstream callers normalize first. Implications These two locations sit in the event-production hot path (agent behavior helpers and the generic event factory), so any caller that forgets to normalize will leak legacy-style references into routing/interpreter logic until EventStore.append eventually normalizes them.
